rspStmt.AuthEnty: NSD - Norwegian Centre for Research Data

Core Scientific Team, consisting of: Roger Jowell (former PI), Rory Fitzgerald (current PI), Eric Harrison, Lorna Ryan, Ana Villar, Sarah Butt, Sally Widdop, Lizzy Gatrell, Yvette Prestage, Mary Keane and Peter Martin: Centre for Comparative Social Surveys (CCSS), City University London, UK. Geert Loosveldt, Jaak Billiet and Hideko Matsuo: Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Belgium. Bjørn Henrichsen, Knut Kalgraff Skjåk, and Kirstine Kolsrud: NSD - Norwegian Centre for Research Data, Norway. Angelika Scheuer, Sabine Häder, Achim Koch, Matthias Ganninger, Verena Halbherr, Brita Dorer and Stefan Zins: GESIS, Germany. Willem Saris, Wiebke Weber, Diana Zavala Rojas and Bruno Arpino: Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Spain. Ineke Stoop, Joost Kappelhof and Henk Fernee: The Netherlands Institute for Social Research (SCP), Netherlands. Brina Malnar: University of Ljubljana, Slovenia.

othId.p: The following groups of people were involved in substantive or advisory capacities at various stages of the project: The Scientific Advisory Board, chaired by Max Kaase. The Methods Group, chaired by Denise Lievesley. The Sampling Expert Panel, headed by Stefan Zins (formerly headed by Matthias Ganninger), GESIS. The Interview Duration Committee, chaired by Piet Bracke. Questionnaire Design Team on Europeans’ Understandings and Evaluations of Democracy, headed by Hanspeter Kriesi, European University Institute (EUI), Florence, Italy. Questionnaire Design Team on Personal and Social Wellbeing, headed by Felicia Huppert from University of Cambridge, UK. Expert on international education classification, Silke Schneider, GESIS . Expert papers on topics for the core questionnaire produced by John Curtice, Robert Eriksson, Jan O. Jonsson, Ken Newton, Shalom Schwartz, Jacques Thomassen and Joachim Vogel.

citation.biblCit: European Social Survey (2014). ESS Round 6 (2012/2013) Technical Report. London: Centre for Comparative Social Surveys, City University London

stdyInfo.abstract:
The European Social Survey (ESS) is an academically-driven multi-country survey, which has been administered in over 30 countries to date. Its three aims are, firstly – to monitor and interpret changing public attitudes and values within Europe and to investigate how they interact with Europe's changing institutions, secondly - to advance and consolidate improved methods of cross-national survey measurement in Europe and beyond, and thirdly - to develop a series of European social indicators, including attitudinal indicators.
In the sixth round, the survey covers 29 countries and employs the most rigorous methodologies. It is funded via the European Commission’s 7th Framework Programme, the European Science Foundation and national funding bodies in each country.
The survey involves strict random probability sampling, a minimum target response rate of 70% and rigorous translation protocols. The hour-long face-to-face interview includes questions on a variety of core topics repeated from previous rounds of the survey and also two modules developed for Round Six covering Europeans’ Understandings and Evaluations of Democracy and Personal and Social Wellbeing (the latter is a partial repeat of a module from round 3).

sumDscr.geogCover: France - France, not including Corsica and other overseas territories.
Iceland - Iceland excluding the islands Vestmannaeyjar, Grimsey, Hrisey and Flatey and very remote rural population.
Israel - Israel and the Jewish population residing in West-Bank.
Spain - Spain, including the North-African cities of Ceuta and Melilla
United Kingdom - The Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and the area north of the Caledonian Canal in Scotland (that is most of the Highlands and the Islands regions) are excluded.
sumDscr.universe: All persons aged 15 and over resident within private households, regardless of their nationality, citizenship, language or legal status, in the following participating countries: European Union countries – Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Hungary, Ireland, Italy, Lithuania, Netherlands, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom. Non-European Union countries: Albania, Iceland, Israel, Kosovo, Norway, Switzerland, Russian Federation, Ukraine.

dataColl.weight:
DESIGN WEIGHTS: The purpose of the design weights (DWEIGHT) is to correct for unequal probabilities for selection due to the sampling design used. In general design weights were computed for each country as follows.
1.w = 1/(PROB1*...*PROBk) is a nx1 vector of weights ; k depends on the number of stages of the sampling design.
2. All weights were rescaled in a way that the sum of the final weights equals n, i.e. Rescaled weights = n*w/sum(w).
POST-STRATIFICATION WEIGHTS: The purpose of the post-stratification weights (PSPWGHT) is to reduce sampling error and non-response bias, using auxiliary information. The ESS post-stratification weights have been constructed using information about age, gender, education and region. The ESS post-stratification weights also adjust for unequal selection probabilities (design weights). A raking procedure has been used in the production of the post-stratification weights. Source population figures: Eurostat. The European Union labour force survey (EU-LFS). For Albania, Iceland, Israel, Kosovo, Norway, Russian Federation, Sweden and Ukraine: ESS Appendix A5 Population Statistics.
POPULATION WEIGHTS: The Population size weight (PWEIGHT) corrects for population size when combining two or more country's data, and is calculated as PWEIGHT=[Population aged 15 years and over]/[(Net sample in data file)*10 000] Source population figures: Eurostat. For Albania and Israel: national statistics. For Kosovo: CIA World Factbook (https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/kv.html)

fileTxt.fileCont: Data from the Main and Supplementary questionnaires. See variable list in Appendix A8.
fileTxt.dataChck: The data file is checked for: duplication of ID numbers, variable names and formats, empty records, wild codes and logical inconsistencies. Missing values have been assigned.
fileTxt.dataMsng: The following missing values have been assigned: 6, 66 etc. = Not applicable 7, 77 etc. = Refusal 8, 88 etc. = Don't know 9, 99 etc. = No answer, i.e. Missing data not elsewhere explained . = Variable not relevant, not deposited, or for other reason omitted from the data file by the archive.

Changes in variables: Variable labels and values have been harmonised for the following variables: ACCDNG, CHPLDM, CHPLDMC, CHPLDMI, CLDGNG, CNTBRTHC, CNTRY, CTSTOGV, CTTRESA, CTTRESAC, CTZSHIPC, DCLVLF, DEAIMPP, DFPRTAL, DFPRTALC, DMCNTOV, DSPPLVT, DSPPLVTC, ENJLF, ENRGLOT, FAIRELC, FAIRELCC, FBRNCNTB, FLAPPPL, FLCLPLA, FLRMS, FLTANX, FLTDPR, FLTEEFF, FLTPCFL, FLTSD, FPLVDM, FPLVDMC, FPLVDMI, GPTPELC, GPTPELCC, GRDFINC, GRDFINCC, GVCODMC, GVCODMI, GVCTZPV, GVCTZPVC, GVEXPDC, GVEXPDCC, GVSPCDM, GVSPDMC, GVSPDMI, ICPART1, IMVTCTZ, INPRDSC, INTEWDE, LCHSHCP, LFWRS, LNGHOM1, LOTSGOT, LRNNTLF, MBRNCNTB, MEDCRGV, MEDCRGVC, MEPRINF, MEPRINFC, NHPFTR, OPPCRGV, OPPCRGVC, OPTFTR, PHYSACT, PLINSOC, PLTAVIE, PLTAVIEC, PPLAHLP, PPLVDMC, PPLVDMI, PRHLPPL, PRTCLCCZ, PRTCLCIL, PRTCLDNL, PRTCLDUA, PRTVTBIL, PRTVTBIT, PRTVTCCZ, PRTVTCES, PRTVTCUA, PRTVTENL, PSTVMS, REGION, REHLPPL, RGHMGPR, RGHMGPRC, RLGDEACH, RLGDEADE, RLGDEARU, RLGDEASE, RLGDEIE, RLGDEIS, RLGDELT, RLGDENL, RLGDENO, RLGDEPT, RLGDNACH, RLGDNADE, RLGDNARU, RLGDNASE, RLGDNIE, RLGDNIS, RLGDNLT, RLGDNNL, RLGDNNO, RLGDNPT, RSHPSTS, SEDIRLF, SLPRL, STPLDMC, STPLDMI, TMABDNG, TMDOTWA, TMENDNG, TMIMDNG, TNAPSUR, TRTRSP, VOTEDIR, WKVLORG, WRBKNRM and WRHPP.
Changes in country data: BULGARIA: F15 (EDULVLB): Category 321 has been recoded to category 323 for 39 cases. Category 423 has been recoded to category 421 for 15 cases. F45 (EDULVLPB): Category 321 has been recoded to category 323 for 17 cases. Category 423 has been recoded to category 421 for 11 cases. F58 (EDULVLFB): Category 321 has been recoded to category 323 for 32 cases. Category 423 has been recoded to category 421 for 5 cases. F64 (EDULVLMB): Category 321 has been recoded to category 323 for 20 cases. Category 423 has been recoded to category 421 for 3 cases. F15 (EISCED): Category 3 has been recoded to category 4 for 39 cases. F45 (EISCEDP): Category 3 has been recoded to category 4 for 17 cases. F58 (EISCEDF): Category 3 has been recoded to category 4 for 32 cases. F64 (EISCEDM): Category 3 has been recoded to category 4 for 20 cases.
CZECH REPUBLIC: F6CZ (RSHPSCZ): Variable removed. F11CZ (MARSTCZ): Variable removed.
IRELAND: B20bIE (PRTCLAIE): Variable has been renamed into PRTCLCIE.
ESS6 edition 2.3 (published 01.12.16): Changes from edition 2.2
Changes in variables: (PSPWGHT): Post-stratification weights have been amended.
Changes in country data: IRELAND: B20bIE (PRTCLAIE): Variable has been renamed into PRTCLCIE.
SLOVAKIA: F15 (EDULVLB): Category 322 has been recoded to category 423 for 30 cases. F45 (EDULVLPB): Category 322 has been recoded to category 423 for 12 cases. F58 (EDULVLFB): Category 322 has been recoded to category 423 for 13 cases. F64 (EDULVLMB): Category 322 has been recoded to category 423 for 15 cases.
SLOVENIA: Data from B13 (WRKORG) have been omitted from the integrated data file. For further details, please see item 46 in the Country reports in the ESS6-2012 Documentation Report.
ESS6 edition 2.2 (published 09.03.16): Changes from edition 2.1
Changes in variables: (PSPWGHT): Post-stratification weights have been corrected.
Changes in country data: CYPRUS: C23 (LNGHOM2): Category 999 "No answer" recoded into 000 "No second language mentioned" in 1025 records.
CZECH REPUBLIC: C23 (LNGHOM2): Category 999 "No answer" recoded into 000 "No second language mentioned" in 1951 records.
DENMARK:
F31 (NACER2): Respondents in the sectors "Agriculture, Forestry and Fishing" or "Mining And Quarrying" have been miscoded into other categories. Values have been replaced for 41 respondents.
FRANCE: F52 (EDULVLFB): Category 5555 "Other" recoded into 8888 "Don't know" in 52 records. F52 (EISCEDF): Category 55 "Other" recoded into 88 "Don't know" in 52 records. F56 (EDULVLMB): Category 5555 "Other" recoded into 8888 "Don't know" in 19 records. F56 (EISCEDM): Category 55 "Other" recoded into 88 "Don't know" in 19 records.
ICELAND: A1 (TVTOT): Category 99 "No answer" recoded into 0 "No time at all" in 7 records.
ISRAEL: F31 (NACER2): Variable was incorrectly coded from 3 to 2 digits. Values have been replaced for all respondents.
ITALY: F53 (EMPRF14): Category 1 "Employee" and 2 "Self-employed" were erroneously reversed. Values have been recoded in 840 records. F57 (EMPRM14): Category 1 "Employee" and 2 "Self-employed" were erroneously reversed. Values have been recoded in 375 records.
POLAND: A2 (TVPOL): Category 66 "Not applicable" recoded into 99 "No answer" in 1 record.
ESS6 edition 2.1 (published 26.11.14): Changes from edition 2.0
Changes in variables: C8 (HLTHHMP): Variable label has been amended.
Changes in country data: ALBANIA: (PSPWGHT): Post-stratification weights have been corrected. (SUPQAD2): Variable has been set to value 1 "Face to face interview" for all cases.
FRANCE: F41 (HINCTNTA): The income categories have been corrected. Category 5 has been recoded to category 1, category 9 has been recoded to category 2, category 1 has been recoded to category 3, category 7 has been recoded to category 4, category 3 has been recoded to category 5, category 10 has been recoded to category 6, category 6 has been recoded to category 7, category 2 has been recoded to category 9 and category 4 has been recoded to category 10.
KOSOVO: (PSPWGHT): Post-stratification weights have been corrected.
LITHUANIA: B12 (PRTVALT1): Variable label has been amended. B12 (PRTVALT2): Variable label has been amended. B12 (PRTVALT3): Variable label has been amended.
SPAIN: (INWTM): Interview length in minutes has been corrected.
SWITZERLAND: (PRTVTDCH): Variable PRTVCH1 has been renamed to PRTVTDCH according to ESS variable name convention. (PRTVCH2): Variable has been removed from the integrated file. PRTVCH2 is available from a separate country specific file for Switzerland at http://www.europeansocialsurvey.org/data/
ESS6 edition 2.0 (published 14.05.14): Changes from edition 1.2
Additional countries : Albania, France, Italy, Lithuania, Ukraine
Changes in variables: Post-stratification weights (variable PSPWGHT) have been added.
Changes in country data: CZECH REPUBLIC: MARITALB: Category 3 "Legally separated" recoded to 4 "Legally divorced/civil union dissolved" in 277 records. Country-specific variables (RSHPSCZ, MARSTCZ) have been added.
GERMANY: F15 (EDUADE1), F44 (EDUPADE1), F52 (EDUFADE1), F56 (EDUMADE1): Value labels have been amended.
HUNGARY: The erroneous data which were removed in ESS6 edition 1.2 have been corrected. All records for Hungary have been reinstated with corrected data.
ISRAEL: F64 (EDUFAIL1): Value labels have been amended.
NORWAY: F33 (ISCO08): Wild code 3440 corrected to category 3430 "Domestic housekeeper" in 1 record.
POLAND: C10 (RLGDNAPL), C12 (RLGDEAPL): Variable name and value labels have been corrected to reflect the changes introduced in ESS5 - 2010.
PORTUGAL: (DWEIGHT): The design weights for Portugal have been corrected.
SLOVENIA: (DWEIGHT): The design weights for Slovenia have been corrected.
UNITED KINGDOM: F15 (EDUGB2), F44 (EDUPGB2), F52 (EDUFGB2), F56 (EDUMGB2): Value labels have been amended.
ESS6 edition 1.2 (published 13.01.14): Changes from edition 1.1
Changes in country data:
HUNGARY: Due to extensive errors in the Hungarian data, all data records for Hungary have been removed. Corrected data for Hungary will be published in the next ESS6 release.
RUSSIAN FEDERATION: An error in the categories in the regional variable for the Russian Federation has been corrected: Values RU15, RU16, RU17 and RU18 have been recoded as follows: RU15=RU16, RU16=RU17, RU17=RU18 and RU18=RU15. In addition there has been a switch in category labels between categories RU11 and RU12. The correct categories and labels are: RU11 Central FO RU12 North-Western FO RU13 Volga FO RU14 South FO RU15 North Caucasian FO RU16 Urals FO RU17 Siberian FO RU18 Far East FO
ESS6 edition 1.1 (published 29.11.13): Changes from edition 1.0
Changes in country data:
HUNGARY: B26 (GINCDIF), B27 (FREEHMS): Due to errors found, data have been removed for Hungary for these variables awaiting possible corrections.
D2 (OPTFTR), D3 (PSTVMS), D4 (FLRMS), D6 (FLTEEFF), D8 (WRHPP), D10 (ENJLF), D11 (FLTSD), D16 (DCLVLF), D17 (LCHSHCP), D18 (ACCDNG), D19 (WRBKNRM), D23 (DNGVAL), D24 (NHPFTR), D25 (LOTSGOT), D26 (LFWRS), D27 (FLCLPLA): Due to errors found, the data for Hungary have been removed for these variables awaiting possible corrections.
ESS6 edition 1.0 (published 30.10.13): Includes data from Belgium, Bulgaria, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Israel, Kosovo, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Russian Federation, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland and United Kingdom.

var.name: ppltrst
var.labl: Most people can be trusted or you can't be too careful

qstn.qstnLit: A3 Using this card, generally speaking, would you say that most people can be trusted, or that you can't be too careful in dealing with people? Please tell me on a score of 0 to 10, where 0 means you can't be too careful and 10 means that most people can be trusted.

var.name: pplfair
var.labl: Most people try to take advantage of you, or try to be fair

qstn.qstnLit: A4 Using this card, do you think that most people would try to take advantage of you if they got the chance, or would they try to be fair?

catgry.labl: Most people try to take advantage of me
Most people try to be fair

var.name: pplhlp
var.labl: Most of the time people helpful or mostly looking out for themselves

qstn.qstnLit: A5 Would you say that most of the time people try to be helpful or that they are mostly looking out for themselves?

catgry.labl: People mostly look out for themselves
People mostly try to be helpful

var.name: polintr
var.labl: How interested in politics

qstn.qstnLit: B1 How interested would you say you are in politics - are you...

var.notes: INTRODUCTION TO QUESTIONS B1-28: Now we want to ask a few questions about politics and government

var.name: trstprl
var.labl: Trust in country's parliament

qstn.qstnLit: B2-8 Using this card, please tell me on a score of 0-10 how much you personally trust each of the institutions I read out. 0 means you do not trust an institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust. Firstly... ...[country]'s parliament?

var.name: trstlgl
var.labl: Trust in the legal system

qstn.qstnLit: B2-8 Using this card, please tell me on a score of 0-10 how much you personally trust each of the institutions I read out. 0 means you do not trust an institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust. Firstly... ...the legal system?

var.name: trstplc
var.labl: Trust in the police

qstn.qstnLit: B2-8 Using this card, please tell me on a score of 0-10 how much you personally trust each of the institutions I read out. 0 means you do not trust an institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust. Firstly... ...the police?

var.name: trstplt
var.labl: Trust in politicians

qstn.qstnLit: B2-8 Using this card, please tell me on a score of 0-10 how much you personally trust each of the institutions I read out. 0 means you do not trust an institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust. Firstly... ...politicians?

var.name: trstprt
var.labl: Trust in political parties

qstn.qstnLit: B2-8 Using this card, please tell me on a score of 0-10 how much you personally trust each of the institutions I read out. 0 means you do not trust an institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust. Firstly... ...political parties?

var.name: trstep
var.labl: Trust in the European Parliament

qstn.qstnLit: B2-8 Using this card, please tell me on a score of 0-10 how much you personally trust each of the institutions I read out. 0 means you do not trust an institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust. Firstly... ...the European Parliament?

var.name: trstun
var.labl: Trust in the United Nations

qstn.qstnLit: B2-8 Using this card, please tell me on a score of 0-10 how much you personally trust each of the institutions I read out. 0 means you do not trust an institution at all, and 10 means you have complete trust. Firstly... ...the United Nations?

Prevented from expressing extreme political views

var.notes: INTRODUCTION TO QUESTIONS E31-45: At the next questions, I'll first ask you to choose between two options. Then I'll ask how important you think your choice is for democracy in general. var.name: ipcrtiv
var.labl: Important to think new ideas and being creative

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. Thinking up new ideas and being creative is important to her/him. She/he likes to do things in her/his own original way.

var.name: imprich
var.labl: Important to be rich, have money and expensive things

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him to be rich. She/he wants to have a lot of money and expensive things.

var.name: ipeqopt
var.labl: Important that people are treated equally and have equal opportunities

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. She/he thinks it is important that every person in the world should be treated equally. She/he believes everyone should have equal opportunities in life.

var.name: ipshabt
var.labl: Important to show abilities and be admired

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It's important to her/him to show her/his abilities. She/he wants people to admire what she/he does.

var.name: impsafe
var.labl: Important to live in secure and safe surroundings

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him to live in secure surroundings. She/he avoids anything that might endanger her/his safety.

var.name: impdiff
var.labl: Important to try new and different things in life

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. She/he likes surprises and is always looking for new things to do. She/he thinks it is important to do lots of different things in life.

var.name: ipfrule
var.labl: Important to do what is told and follow rules

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. She/he believes that people should do what they're told. She/he thinks people should follow rules at all times, even when no-one is watching.

var.name: ipudrst
var.labl: Important to understand different people

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him to listen to people who are different from her/him. Even when she/he disagrees with them, she/he still wants to understand them.

var.name: ipmodst
var.labl: Important to be humble and modest, not draw attention

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him to be humble and modest. She/he tries not to draw attention to herself/himself.

var.name: ipgdtim
var.labl: Important to have a good time

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. Having a good time is important to her/him. She/he likes to 'spoil' herself/himself.

var.name: impfree
var.labl: Important to make own decisions and be free

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him to make her/his own decisions about what she/he does. She/he likes to be free and not depend on others.

var.name: iphlppl
var.labl: Important to help people and care for others well-being

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It's very important to her/him to help the people around her/him. She/he wants to care for their well-being.

var.name: ipsuces
var.labl: Important to be successful and that people recognize achievements

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. Being very successful is important to her/him. She/he hopes people will recognise her/his achievements.

var.name: ipstrgv
var.labl: Important that government is strong and ensures safety

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him that the government ensures her/his safety against all threats. She/he wants the state to be strong so it can defend its citizens.

var.name: ipadvnt
var.labl: Important to seek adventures and have an exciting life

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. She/he looks for adventures and likes to take risks. She/he wants to have an exciting life.

var.name: ipbhprp
var.labl: Important to behave properly

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him always to behave properly. She/he wants to avoid doing anything people would say is wrong.

var.name: iprspot
var.labl: Important to get respect from others

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him to get respect from others. She/he wants people to do what she/he says.

var.name: iplylfr
var.labl: Important to be loyal to friends and devote to people close

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. It is important to her/him to be loyal to her/his friends. She/he wants to devote herself/himself to people close to her/him.

var.name: impenv
var.labl: Important to care for nature and environment

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. She/he strongly believes that people should care for nature. Looking after the environment is important to her/him.

var.name: imptrad
var.labl: Important to follow traditions and customs

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. Tradition is important to her/him. She/he tries to follow the customs handed down by her/his religion or her/his family.

var.name: impfun
var.labl: Important to seek fun and things that give pleasure

qstn.qstnLit: Ha-u Now I will briefly describe some people. Please listen to each description and tell me how much each person is or is not like you. Use this card for your answer. She/he seeks every chance she/he can to have fun. It is important to her/him to do things that give her/him pleasure.

var.notes: Common region variable for all participating countries, with NUTS units for countries included in the Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics (NUTS), and nationally defined units for others. For documentation of country-wise categories, please see item 40 in the ESS6 - 2012 Documentation Report or in Appendix A6. Cyprus, Israel: No regional units below country level due to anonymity concerns. Finland, Russian Federation: The country-specific region categories have changed since ESS5 - 2010.
